newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia to work on a benchmark for bond market.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia to work on a benchmark for bond market.

text.p: Indonesia's central bank governor said on Thursday the bank was working with the International Finance Corporation (IFC) to set up a benchmark for its local bond market.

"The needs are .. pressing for a benchmark. We hope that it will be filled by multilateral agencies .. something which we later on can approve," Bank Indonesia Governor Sudradjad Djiwandono told an international business conference.
"There has been discussion for more than a year between us and IFC about issuing rupiah bonds," Djiwandono said.
He told the conference if the agency could issue bonds on a regular basis to finance its projects in Indonesia, they could be used as a benchmark for corporate bonds.
He later told reporters that there was no bond market in Indonesia as locally issued bonds were bought "for keeps" and not traded because of the lack of a benchmark.
IFC, the International Finance Corporation, is a member of the World Bank Group focusing on loan financing for private sector projects in developing countries.
Djiwandono said, however, the government itself had no plans to issue bonds domestically because Indonesia's budget was always balanced by law, since 1967.
He said the government can issue bonds in offshore markets, as it did in July with a $350 million issue in New York, but not in the domestic market.
He added there were some 50 corporations in Indonesia which had issued bonds, but the secondary market was still inactive.
"The lack of a benchmark, the lack of liquidity, the absence of a central clearing and custody body as well as various other problems still impede its progress," Djiwandono said.
